awd_titl_txt: Researching Equity, Access, & Learning in CS Education (REAL-CS): Scaling and Sustainability in High School Computer Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of California Los Angeles, in collaboration with the University of Oregon, is working to assure that equity remains central to the growing Exploring Computer Science (ECS) program and larger CSforAll movement. Over the last five years, broadening participation in computing efforts have ignited a national movement to bring computer science (CS) education to schools across the U.S. As school districts and entire states rush to get CS teachers and curricula in place, it is critically important to retain the focus on equity.

This project -- Researching Equity, Access, & Learning in CS Education (REAL-CS) -- has three principal strands of work, each guided by an overarching research agenda that focuses on the experiences and perspectives of students, teachers, and grassroots and policy makers across varied settings. The three strands are:

(1) ECS Program Support, Outreach, and Research Nationwide which will continue to scale the ECS program, increasing the number and capacity of inquiry and equity-based ECS teachers, and deepening the learning and collaboration between ECS projects in varied settings.

(2) Sustaining and Building Capacity for Computer Science Education Through Public Engagement which will support active public engagement from the grassroots, such as parent organizations, to policy and governing bodies that have jurisdiction over issues of issues of equity and CS education.

(3) CS Educational Equity Research which will do qualitative research (interviews, classroom observations, focus groups) across a set of different educational contexts (e.g., urban vs. rural classrooms) and CSforAll professional development opportunities in order to document the impacts of recent CS reform efforts on broadening participation. The engagement, learning, and sense of belonging (or not) of students of color and females -- groups traditionally marginalized by the CS field -- will be given special emphasis.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
The REAL-CS Broadening Participation in Computing (BPC) Alliance focuses on developing, supporting, and researching how to support diverse students in high school computer science (CS) education through a research-based, equity-focused approach. 

The project supported national distribution of the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) program, a year-long high school course. First developed with the BPC “Into the Loop” award in 2008, ECS broadens participation in CS through inquiry-based, inclusive, daily lesson plans covering foundational topics of CS, including units on AI and ETextiles. The online professional learning platform ECS developed pre-pandemic allowed for a successful pivot to online professional development (PD) for teachers in 2020. ECS materials have been downloaded over 8,000 times, and remain freely available to the public at exploringcs.org. 

ECS teachers attend a 2-year PD program and a key Alliance activity has been growing a national cadre of over 40 ECS teacher facilitators who co-facilitate ECS PDs, and gather annually to update their professional facilitation skills. Establishing this group of experienced teacher facilitators ensures that ECS PD sessions are marked by quality, consistency, equity, and informed by the cycle of Alliance-related research. 

Our robust Alliance partners hold common equity goals, shared curricular resources, learning agendas, and data collection. Our partners reach across 16 states, regions, and territories to expand capacity for ECS courses in local schools. To provide opportunities for rural schools, we also supported 3 teacher cohorts at national ECS PDs. In total, REAL-CS has prepared 1420 teachers to teach ECS, who reach an estimated 35 thousand students annually. This adds to the cadre of existing ECS teachers prepared with prior NSF-funded support. In total, the ECS project has prepared 3500 teachers in PD, who teach an estimated 87,000 students annually. 

REAL-CS has provided intellectual contributions through the generation of ECS-related publications, including dozens of articles and conference presentations providing empirical data around equitable CS curriculum and professional learning. The ECS program was featured in the recent National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Computing’s “Cultivating Interest and Competencies in Computing” report. This research has impacted educators for elevating race-conscious approaches in CS, and developing methodological approaches, such as survey items woven into the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) teacher survey. 

Another line of Alliance research amplifies ECS students’ voices from urban and rural contexts (California and Mississippi), to understand what influences engagement and agency with computing for underrepresented students. Research findings from the Alliance about  students’ perspectives were published in videos, webinars, podcasts, academic articles, and a graphic novel (Power On!, MIT Press 2022) that addresses issues of equity and ethics in computing. This book - meant to engage youth, educators, and families with CS education and topics in accessible and relevant ways - includes a free facilitator resource (created by CSTA Equity Fellows) and is currently used in CS formal and out-of-school programs nationwide (including Girls Who Code, NYC public schools, etc.). 

In addition to focusing on teachers and students, we are building system capacity and public engagement with CS education by informing policy partners about educators’ experiences. Building on our research-practice-partnership, Supporting Computing Access, Leadership, and Equity in California (SCALE-CA) grant (#1837780), we co-created a CS Equity Guide and accompanying CS Equity Workshop for School Leaders while piloting a comprehensive professional learning model, Seasons of CS, geared toward teachers, counselors, and school leaders. Through REAL-CS we have scaled and sustained the Seasons of CS PD program to expandcapacity building activities with school leaders, while simultaneously informing state-level policy changes that subsequently supported local and statewide expansion of equity minded CS across California.

Inspired by our collaborative work with ECS leadership and research shared from prior CSPD weeks, REAL-CS activities have resulted in major California investments in Seasons of CS including $20 million dollar appropriation through the California Department of Education’s Educator Workforce Investment Grant. From our earliest pilot in 2019 with 123 participants, Summer of CS has grown to include ongoing professional learning for 659 participants in 2023, including teachers, counselors, and administrators across California. Our Train the Trainer program for the CS Equity Guide and Workshop for School Leaders prepared 20 California educators and, through our involvement in Expanding Computing Education Pathways, 20 educators from 7 other states who are adapting it for their regions. REAL-CS activities shared with colleagues nationwide are informing statewide initiatives from Oregon to Massachusetts. We also disseminate learning through our multi-stakeholder CSforCA coalition whose bi-monthly newsletter reaches over 1,400 subscribers, and whose website has over 18,000 visitors a year, Twitter account has over 1,400 followers, and new LinkedIn Page has 46 followers.  Along with regular webinars, policy briefs, and events, we keep stakeholders abreast of actions they can take in their schools, across their local education agencies, and in their state’s capital to expand equity, access, and engagement in CS education.

 


Last Modified: 12/31/2023
Modified by: Joanna Goode

The online professional learning platform ECS developed pre-pandemic allowed for a successful pivot to online professional development (PD) for teachers in 2020. Establishing this group of experienced teacher facilitators ensures that ECS PD sessions are marked by quality, consistency, equity, and informed by the cycle of Alliance-related research.

Inspired by our collaborative work with ECS leadership and research shared from prior CSPD weeks, REAL-CS activities have resulted in major California investments in Seasons of CS including $20 million dollar appropriation through the California Department of Educations Educator Workforce Investment Grant.
